FeedItems.Summary: We are excited to announce that nuget.org now supports package deprecation. This has been a long standing ask that will help the ecosystem use supported packages. As a package publisher on nuget.org,...

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Auxiliary2AzureSearch is stuck on PROD due to too many download count decreases" (#7694) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The limit of download count decreases is 15,000 today (the previous highest we saw was in the 10K-15K range. There are now 27,766 decreases.

Root cause is unknown but perhaps the downloads.v1.json file was generated during a very large roll-up.

/cc @scottbommarito who is on-call.

Release: [508048](https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_releaseProgress?_a=release-pipeline-progress&releaseId=508048)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Because the old accounts are disabled, I cannot access my profile" (#7659) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Closed issue "[Gravatar Proxy] Handle "Service Unavailable" responses" (#7646) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
About ~10 times an hour, Gravatar responds with a HTTP 503 (see [this query](https://ms.portal.azure.com#@33e01921-4d64-4f8c-a055-5bdaffd5e33d/blade/Microsoft_Azure_Monitoring_Logs/LogsBlade/resourceId/%2Fsubscriptions%2F685c4662-53d8-40f9-ac51-926097ede041%2FresourceGroups%2Fnuget-prod-0-v2gallery%2Fproviders%2Fmicrosoft.insights%2Fcomponents%2Fnuget-prod-v2gallery/source/LogsBlade.AnalyticsShareLinkToQuery/q/H4sIAAAAAAAAA0WNQQqDMBBF955i6EpBpB7Abgq9RhknHw2YRGaSlpYevtaF3f73Ht9hRXSI4mHVh54zFJR9gGUOK12Ip1T3Z9f8IeuETMNAJ4MURTcpP3ibO0nhRIdoRQRmu3njxbAzKyGw%252BjdIUom5bmh80ehjfZy21M9NSworS74mh61K6qA%252Fc4%252Fu5GBC1RepItIovQAAAA%253D%253D)). As a result, the browser displays a broken image to the user until the user refreshes the page. This affects 0.18% of the Gallery's Gravatar requests (see [this query](https://ms.portal.azure.com#@33e01921-4d64-4f8c-a055-5bdaffd5e33d/blade/Microsoft_Azure_Monitoring_Logs/LogsBlade/resourceId/%2Fsubscriptions%2F685c4662-53d8-40f9-ac51-926097ede041%2FresourceGroups%2Fnuget-prod-0-v2gallery%2Fproviders%2Fmicrosoft.insights%2Fcomponents%2Fnuget-prod-v2gallery/source/LogsBlade.AnalyticsShareLinkToQuery/q/H4sIAAAAAAAAA0XNOw6EMBAD0J5TWFRsww3ot6TgArODBSkSokkCAnF4Ps22z5Y9MjKMDOqYqhPbTCPyHomuQ%252F0dhr7G38Um5jdJ1GJsJ5NVbm518W8xFe%252FF3EHoUkJuPvjtN6oyPfv2nBmio85iGdUFsVJFjYAAAAA%253D/timespan/P1D)). It's hard to measure the actual customer impact as customers' browsers cache the Gravatar images.

### To Reproduce
Unknown. This seems to be due to issues in Gravatar.

### Expected behavior
Consider showing a fallback image instead.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The uploaded symbols package contains one or more pdbs that are not portable. " (#7668) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I am not able to upload a generated snupkg to Nuget.org. During indexing it always reports this error "The uploaded symbols package contains one or more pdbs that are not portable."

TargetFramework: netstandard2.0
Visual Studio: 16.3.4
DebugType: portable

This is how I pack: `dotnet pack .\Firebase.csproj --include-symbols -p:SymbolPackageFormat=snupkg -p:configuration=Release`

Here's the full csproj (which specifies `DebugType` as `portable`: https://github.com/step-up-labs/firebase-database-dotnet/blob/master/src/Firebase/Firebase.csproj
Package on nuget: https://www.nuget.org/packages/FirebaseDatabase.net/

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Point api/v2/curated-feeds to main V2 feed" (#7697) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Address https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7689.

This helps reduce code and makes the server-side cache be shared between two endpoints that currently behave the almost the same. Differences are: 

1. The `/Packages()` endpoint returned at most 40 on the curated feed controller. This will become 100 which is the max in the non-curated feed controller.
1. Non-existent curated feeds will now 200 and behave no different than the "microsoftdotnet" feed. Note that "microsoftdotnet" accounts for 99.89% of the requests so I don't think this is a big deal.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Decouple Settings & SettingsFile objects" (#8811) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The motivation for this comes from: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/3086
Settings objects own a bunch of SettingsFiles. 
The SettingsFiles themselves have priority in that Settings object.
The fact that a Settings object changes the SettingsFile object it uses, the caching cannot be done on that level. 

Because SettingsFile is the origin for every settings item, the priority needs to be understood at the settings object level in order to perform the updates correctly.

See: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/48f67796ff38e98e3dfe4ab55fce000577b74fea/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Configuration/PackageSource/PackageSourceProvider.cs#L86

https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/48f67796ff38e98e3dfe4ab55fce000577b74fea/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Configuration/Settings/Settings.cs#L233

The above 2 now make use of the ConfigFilePaths returning the config paths in the correct priority.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Concurrent nuget install failures" (#7380) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We are using TeamCity with multiple agents on the same physical machine. We want to have all the agents share the same global packages folder to save disk space. Even then, it is not enough and we clear the packages from time to time. The result is that we have only one shared global packages folder, but install and restore operations fail regularly after we clear the locals caches.

We get errors like these
- `Access to the path 'bqipdjvv.1mg' is denied.`
- `The directory is not empty.`

Unfortunately, the NuGetScratch folder is located under the `%temp%` folder which TeamCity override per agent. What we understand is that the scratch folder is used to lock the downloads and installs of packages in the global cache. If we try to install the same package for the first time from different `nuget install` at the same time, the second will wait for the first one to finish without problem. 
However, if I repeat the experiment with different `%temp%` at least one of the `nuget install` will fail.

Is there any reason that the NuGetScratch folder is located in `%temp%` while other NuGet folders are in `%localappdata%` or the user folder?

Do you think there is a way to make this work anyway? I mean using nuget from different TeamCity agents sharing the same global packages folder but not the same `%temp%` folder?

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Error occurred while restoring NuGet packages: The operation failed as details for project ClassLibrary1 could not be loaded." (#8813) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

Open attached solution in Visual Studio
and try to compile it. It will create an error message during build
'Error occurred while restoring NuGet packages: The operation failed
as details for project ClassLibrary1 could not be loaded.'

The reason is that it has two targets and a assembly name that changes
depending on target version. This causes an InvalidOperationException
in VsNominationUtilities ~Line 300:
`GetNonEvaluatedPropertyOrNull(values, propertyName, valueFactory).SingleOrDefault()`
that is invoked by 
`internal static string GetPackageId(ProjectNames projectNames, IEnumerable tfms)`
as two package ID's are resolved (one for each assembly name).

This further causes that no restore entry is created in the project
system cache and then will cause this build error.

- NuGet product used: Visual Studio build with package restore enabled
- Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: Don't think so.
- VS version (if appropriate): Version 16.4.0 Preview 4.0

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Open attached solution in Visual Studio
1. build
1. See build output

## Other suggested things
A workaround is to set an explicit 'PackageId' for ClassLibrary1.
But it took me one day of debugging the NuGet extension to find that IMO workaround.

So some fix, or at least better log output when the cache entry cannot be created would
be nice. If i saw correctly, the exception during cache creation is simply swallowed
(at least in normal builds without special logging enabled etc.) and
and creates followup issues later. Very annoying.

### Sample Project
[ConsoleApp27.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/3839653/ConsoleApp27.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Warning NU5048: The 'PackageIconUrl'/'iconUrl' element is deprecated with 3.0.100-preview9-014004" (#8569) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
_From @kdcllc on Thursday, September 5, 2019 4:49:06 PM_

This warning is displayed with DotNetCore 3.0.100-preview9-014004 with the following tag:
 ```
<PackageIconUrl>https://github.com/kdcllc/Bet.AspNetCore/raw/master/img/logo64x64.png</PackageIconUrl>
```
When changed to `<PackageIcon>` the sdk msbuild action is not able to find the local file.


_Copied from original issue: dotnet/core-sdk#4588_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue " [Test Failure] Package icon becomes a default icon after installing ‘Newtonsoft.Json’ with latest versoin" (#8814) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet Version: Dev\5.5.0.6293
VS Version: VS Master\29512.44
OS Version: Windows-10-Enterprise-19H1-04-05-2019

## Installation step:

[https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3236483&view=results](url)
 
## Repro steps: 

1. Create a C# Console App (.Net Core) project.
2. Open ‘Manage NuGet Packages’.
3. Install package ‘Newtonsoft.Json’ with latest version 12.0.3.
4. Go to the ‘Installed’ tab and observe the icon of package ‘Newtonsoft.Json’.

## Expected:
The package icon under ‘Installed’ tab should be same as ‘Browse’ tab.

## Actual:
The package icon becomes default icon under ‘Installed’ tab as below screenshot.
![bug1113](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20632775/68749905-f31eb580-0639-11ea-9457-3c27aa7650e7.png)

## Notes: 
1. The issue not repro after installing package ‘Newtonsoft.Json’ with an older version.
2. The issue repro on D16.4\29512.137 with implicit NuGet Client Release-5.4.x\5.4.0.6292.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Localization validator fails on official builds" (#8816) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:

https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=3216283

Likely becausae the validator doesn't run on local builds. 

Fix and enable validator on local builds

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "PackageSource.ProtocolVersion gives wrong value" (#8819) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: If you have a source in your `nuget.config` that uses a v3 source, for example `https://source.test/index.json`, but no `protocolVersion` attribute, `PackageSource.ProtocolVersion` will return `2`, even though using it with `NuGet.Protocol` will use the v3 code.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "HttpRequestMessage gets reused multiple times which is not supported with the SocketHttpHandler" (#8661) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "Write an official setup-nuget-exe github action" (#8818) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "HttpRequestMessage gets reused multiple times which is not supported with the SocketHttpHandler" (#8661) at NuGet/Home
Opened issue "In old style PackageReference - PM UI installed packages might be out of date with the assets file." (#8817) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
See: 

https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/797709/nuget-project-reference-not-shown.html?childToView=818232

The references node depends on the assets file, while the PM UI shows the csproj reference, since autorestore is not a thing, they can easily get out of date. 

A potential improvement on NuGet PM UI can be to indicate that restore is not up to date but that's tricky to figure out right now. 

Given that a restore fixes the problem, the priority for this is a bit lower.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "New and improved NuGet Search is live!" (#38) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Announcing the new and improved search on NuGet.org leveraging Azure Search.
